categories.name: Insufficient Philosophical Content
categories.description: Passage lacks any philosophical content or sufficient load-bearing philosophical presuppositions.

categories.name: Insufficient Context
categories.description: Passage lacks sufficient context to reliably identify philosophical presuppositions. Multiple interpretations are equally plausible without additional context.

categories.name: Physicalism and Naturalism
categories.description: The view that everything supervenes on the physical; reality conforms entirely to what physics describes. Naturalism holds reality contains no supernatural entities and scientific methods provide our theoretical understanding.

categories.name: Anti-Reductionism
categories.description: Some phenomena (consciousness, meaning, intentionality, normativity, value) resist reduction to physical description. Indicates that mind and body are fundamentally distinct kinds.

categories.name: Determinism and Free Will
categories.description: Determinism: every event is necessitated by prior events and laws of nature. Free will: agents have capacity to be ultimate source of their actions. Compatibilism holds both can be consistent.

categories.name: Empiricism
categories.description: Knowledge about the world comes entirely from sense experience. All justification must ultimately trace to evidence. Rejects innate knowledge.

categories.name: Rationalism
categories.description: Significant knowledge is gained through reason, independent of experience. Some propositions are knowable by intellectual intuition or deduction.

categories.name: Relativism and Objectivism
categories.description: Relativism: truth, right/wrong, standards of reasoning are products of contextual frameworks. Objectivism: these norms are universal and mind-independent.

categories.name: Consequentialism
categories.description: An act is morally right if it produces the best overall outcome. Morally correct actions are defined by their relationship to good outcomes. Features maximisation, aggregation, and forward-looking assessment.

categories.name: Deontology
categories.description: Certain actions are right or wrong regardless of consequences, based on conformity to moral rules, duties, or principles. What is 'Right' is prior to the 'Good'.

categories.name: Virtue Ethics
categories.description: Virtues and moral character are fundamental. Virtues are excellent traits of character. Practical wisdom is the ability to recognise appropriate responses. Flourishing (eudaimonia) is the good human life.

categories.name: Individualism
categories.description: Individuals are the basic, morally primary units of political analysis. Individual autonomy should be prioritised. Legitimate institutions secure liberties and resources for freely chosen lives.

categories.name: Communitarianism
categories.description: Human identities are shaped by communities. Community bonds and collective obligations should be emphasised. Standards of justice found in traditions of particular societies.

categories.name: State Neutrality and Perfectionism
categories.description: Whether the state should promote substantive conceptions of the good life (perfectionism) or remain neutral. Neutrality: state shouldn't promote the good without consent. Perfectionism: promotion of the good is morally consistent.
